text:
2:43pm PT by Scott Feinberg Academy President on Trump's Travel Ban: "Art Has No Borders" Earl Gibson III/WireImage Cheryl Boone Isaacs As she welcomed guests to the annual Nominees Luncheon, Cheryl Boone Isaacs said the Academy has made "real progress" in terms of inclusion and diversity. 
“Each and every one of us knows that there are some empty chairs in this room, which makes all of us activists,” Cheryl Boone Isaacs, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, said Monday as she welcomed guests to the Academy’s annual Nominees Luncheon, held at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. 
The event celebrates all the nominees for the 89th Academy Awards, which will be held Feb. 26. But President Trump’s travel ban, which is currently on hold because of a temporary restraining order issued by U.S. District Court Judge James Robert in Seattle, has already impacted attendance at this year’s Oscars. In a statement issued Jan. 29, Iranian director Asghar Farhadi, whose film The Salesman is nominated for best foreign-language film, said he will not attend the awards because of the executive order which he condemned as “unjust.” 
While Boone Isaacs did not mention Trump by name, she said, “Art has no borders,” continuing, “Strong societies don’t censor art, they celebrate it,” and adding, “Borders cannot be allow to stop any of us,” drawing a big round of applause. 
In her opening remarks, the Academy president also acknowledged the efforts the Academy has made in the name of diversity and inclusion. “Wow, what a difference a year makes,” she said, to further applause, a reference to the fact that this year there are many more nominees of color, particularly in the acting categories, which had been branded #OscarsSoWhite during the past two years. 
“Real progress has been made — progress that I am confident will continue in the future,” she said. “When we reach out to be inclusive, we set an important example,” she contended, saying, "We become agents of change." Scott Feinberg
